text: We have extensive tests that run before we make changes to the code, so a problem with the pressure solver is unlikely (but still possible if you are using the code in a way that is not tested). In particular, we test that set! works on the CPU and GPU. As for your second question — if you are referring to things that go wrong if you build Oceananigans in an environment without CUDA, but later try to use the build to run code on GPUs — information about common pitfalls during installation (especially on clusters) should be in the docs but may not be unfortunately! It’s not due to changes in Oceananigans though!

text: Keeping track of GitHub is definitely the best way to stay abreast of changes. We also try to summarize things that have changed every time we make a release (update oceananigans version). You should also use Julia environments for your code, so that you always know what version of oceananigans you are using (and you can keep the oceananigans version fixed, so that you are not constantly updating your scripts to keep pace with oceananigans development).
